BE11:16am

Markets are understandably weary about Brexit developments. But after last
night's second defeat for Prime Minister May's Brexit deal, more clarity is
emerging about the end game.
First, the Prime Minister has committed to holding a free vote this evening
on leaving without a deal. We expect Parliament to overwhelmingly reject this proposal. A second vote will be held on Thursday as to whether to extend Article 50. We expect Parliament to support an extension of Article 50. It is not yet clear how the motion will be constructed, and whether MPs will be given the opportunity to support a particular length of extension. If this is the case, we would expect MPs to vote for a short extension (up until the May EU elections). But MPs do not get to set the length of any extension - that requires consent from the EU27.
Second, the EU27's position on an extension of Article 50 beyond the 28th March is becoming clearer. As indicated by comments from Commission President Juncker, Chief Negotiator Barnier and Dutch PM Rutte, there will be no further discussions on the existing Withdrawal Agreement.1 The EU27 will be willing to consider an extension, but only with a credible proposal from the UK government as to an alternative negotiating stance, or in order to allow the UK to hold new elections or a second referendum. No extension will be granted on the basis of continuing talks on the backstop. A formal EU response on an extension
will emerge by the EU Council on the 21/22nd March. We anticipate the EU27 will offer either a short extension based on the UK government providing a credible alternative plan, or an open ended longer extension, requiring the UK to participate in the EU Parliament elections and make additional budgetary contributions.

BE11:16am

Third, Prime Minister May indicated last night she would be prepared to hold indicative votes in parliament on alternative Brexit proposals, seemingly after the votes today and tomorrow. Prime Minister May framed this choice as between a revocation of Article 50, a second referendum or a different deal to her own. The timing and structure of such votes has yet to be decided. We do not
anticipate parliamentary support for either a revocation of Article 50 or second referendum if these votes were held today. It may be possible for Parliament to reach consensus on an alternative deal to Prime Minister May's. In particular, should Parliament agree on changes to the Political Declaration on the Future

just looking Free vote Malthouse
red as i keep saying,mkt will buy sterling dips. it believes there will be no brexit/soft brexit. cant fight tape, so go with it. but in the end i expect they will be wrong.
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Relationship, committing the UK to either a permanent customs union or Norway plus Brexit, this is likely to be an outcome the EU27 would treat favourably.
Taking 1, 2 and 3 together, the direction of travel in the next two and a half weeks has become clearer. Having voted to extend Article 50, Parliament will have the opportunity to form a consensus on an alternative plan to May's deal. The one credible alternative we see are changes to the Political Declaration on the Future Relationship in the direction of a softer Brexit. Should consensus not be formed, May will be presented with a choice at the EU Council on the 21/22nd December - a long extension or a no deal Brexit at the end of the month. It is also possible that a long extension is not offered, and in the absence of a credible plan, the EU27 provides the UK with a choice with revoking Article 50 or a no deal Brexit, although we see this as a more unlikely scenario.
In this scenario, pressure will be back on MPs in the week before Brexit. Ratify May's deal at the third time of asking, or accept a long extension of Article
50 with the resulting political costs associated with UK participation in the EU Parliament elections and further budgetary contributions. Our baseline as of our note yesterday is May's deal will then be ratified at the third time of asking. The main no deal risk associated with this scenario is that MPs vote explicitly for a short extension on Thursday, fail to reach consensus on an alternative form of Brexit plan (or reach consensus on a non credible alternative), May rejects the EU27 request for a long extension, and MPs reject May's Brexit deal at the third time of asking in the last week of March, leading the UK into no deal.

Updated probabilities
1. Parliament fails to vote for an extension of Article 50 on Thursday raising risks of no deal - 5% probability (formerly 5%)
2. MPs form consensus over second referendum in indicative votes - 10%
probability (formerly 10%)
3. MPs form consensus over softer Brexit in indicative votes - 30% probability
5. MPs form consensus to revoke Article 50 in indicative votes - 5% probability
6. MPs fail to form consensus on an alternative plan, and instead ratify May's deal in last week of March after EU offers long extension/no extension - 30% (formerly 30%)
7. MPs fail to form consensus on an alternative plan, but fail to ratify May's deal in last week of March after EU offers long extension/no extension. No deal Brexit - 10%
8. Early election called by May - 10% probability (formerly 20%)

Citi can summarise:

11:33 am
BE11:33am

 Citi's Take — Outflows were well known: SLA focus is on other positive messages instead. Cost savings ahead of plan, streamlined management, commitment to maintain DPS “during the period of transformation” should be well received. Alongside moves to liquidate investment stakes on Monday, outlook ex-flows looks good.
 Board Change — Many investors have been expecting some change since Sir Douglas Flint became Chair at the start of this year. As of today, single CEO (Keith Skeoch) and from 1 June, new CFO (Stephanie Bruce).
 Costs — £1.4bn costs, down 10% yoy, helped by plans to target £350m merger and model simplification savings. Integration ahead of schedule, actions already taken to deliver £175m savings, of which £120m seen in 2018. SLA also achieved a further reduction in underlying costs of £56m due to other efficiencies.
 Earnings (see p. 2-3) — £650m PBT was 9% ahead of Citi, 5% consensus: £510m Asset Management and Platform (Citi £515m) and £140m Associates/JVs (£80m).
 £40.9bn net outflows — vs. Citi £46.0bn and Consensus £40.3bn. £551.5bn AuM 3% better than Citi £536.0bn. More equity and less Strategic Insurance Partners outflows than we expected, and more slowdown in Elevate/Wrap flows 1H-2H.
 Questions — Reasons for DPS confidence, Plans for £0.6bn surplus capital, full £750m buyback (£358m so far), further investment stake sales, further cost savings. Outlook for flow recovery, impact of Elevate platform fee cuts. Meeting at 9.30AM.
 Implications — SLA has a “good pipeline of new business” and continues with “new product launches” in New Active, e.g. GCC infrastructure and Asian direct real estate. Shares have fallen -5% YTD, and trade at 12.5x 2019E, 8.7% dividend yield, but only ~4x on core asset management earnings after adjusting for investment stake values. Buy/High Risk on capital returns and valuation, any signs of fundamental flow recovery through 2019E would be even better.

BE11:36am

These are messy results: adj reported PBT at £650m is ahead of expectations, but is more skewed towards insurance associated and JVs than forecast. Together with AUM slightly below consensus and our £565.6bn, we now need to assess the impact on the underlying asset management and platform profitability going forward. We note that the company believes it is ahead of schedule in delivering cost efficiencies. The company has at least committed to holding the 2018 DPS flat during a period of transformation, but the question remains as to when it can grow.
Valuation
SLA trades at c. 11x 2019e earnings and the 21.6p dividend represents an 8.8% yield. We use a SOTP model to value SLA, producing a PT of 410p including the listed value of its associates, but we need to review our forecasts.

Confirms unsolicited offer for travel businesses. After the close yesterday CPI confirmed that, following media speculation, several weeks ago it received an unsolicited offer for its travel businesses from Australia’s Corporate Travel Management (MCap £1.4bn). Given the stage of discussions, which are ongoing, there is no certainty that the disposal will complete/of the transition consideration. Capita Travel & Events, which is reported within Specialist Services, delivered £13.3m EBITA on £44.4m revs (30% margin) in FY17.

11:48 am

Panmure can whip through where we are.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

The beginning of a period of significant change, Dignity reduced funeral
prices, created a broader product range and initiated a 3-year transformation plan - the latter of which is expected to generate significant cost synergies FY20+. FY18 Group EBITA was c£1.6m ahead of cons (£80.2m vs/ £78.6m), with Crematoria continuing to perform strongly. Consumer responses to price changes enacted Jan-18 have resulted in an improvement in DTY’s Funeral Services market share (after two years of decline) and the macro environment remains conducive to growth medium-term. We maintain our Buy recommendation but lower our DCF-derived target price to 900p (from 1410p), reflective of a challenging operating environment and the potential consequences of the CMA review.

BE11:50am

U pdated forecasts. Management have guided to a blended average Funeral Services income of £2,940 in FY19 (less than 1% lower than FY18 which we view as positive). We update our FY19 model assumptions accordingly, assuming Funeral Services EBITDA softens slightly due to increased Transformation Plan cost. For prudence, we remain at the top end of guidance with respect to likely central cost expansion. No fundamental changes to other guidance and we continue to assume ‘solid, single-digit increases’ in underlying EPS. We also release our FY21 forecast.
 P re-need / HMT. We remind investors that the addressable pre-need market has shrunk due to negative publicity and has become significantly more competitive with more sales online and more cold-calling from some competitors. HM Treasury is continuing its consultation into the pre-paid funeral plan market (announced H1/18),
with the option to formally regulate the market via the FCA. DTY has led calls in recent years for regulation and its research, published together with Fairer Finance, has highlighted the poor sales practices and financial management risks that certain providers engage in. An update is expected from HMT H1/19, though there is no formal timeline.

GBKrona @BE - Prudential plc pls
red @Pharmanot a question of escaping as its a trading partner and actually being in the eu is a set of rules thats all. the uk has decided it wants a different set of rules, in return for looser ties. but to start discussing those, the uk needs to leave first. for the uk, leaving with no deal means its hands are not tied in negotiating the fta. for the eu, the WA works in its favour. so there you have the two sides.

11:51 am

BE11:52am

PBT fell by 30% to £54.4m as expected and our forecast of
£44.5m for 2019 is unchanged due to a further decline in pricing
in funeral homes (c£30), higher central costs (marketing,
technology) and lower pre-need profits. Pricing in Funeral
Homes is higher than originally expected, but costs are higher to
offset.
There is no mention of current trading in the release, but Q1 will
be sharply lower as the death-rate is currently -12% (due to a
high death-rate last year and lower flue incidence). Q1 is an
important period and profits are likely to be

50% down. In the

FY the death-rate is likely to balance out, but may well be below
last year.
In reality, this is all short-term noise. The real issue is the CMA
review and potential for a Market Investigation. This will run on
for some time, but the direction of travel is clear given the
CMA’s initial findings.

BE11:58am

A lot of people looked at Vannin, thought "um, this is a bit wild" and started picking at Burford as a result. Those arguments seem to have died down of late though. Here's Berenberg.

BE11:59am

Another good year: In FY 2018, Burford earned revenue of $420m (up 12%
versus consensus, up 23% yoy) and adjusted profit before tax of $316m (up 5% versus consensus 19% yoy). As in FY 2017, 93% of revenue was
generated by the litigation finance business, which represents the return
on Burford’s own capital. Investment Management was flat yoy, but Asset
Recovery and Insurance both increased yoy. Burford is the clear market
leader with $2.5bn in investments, 55 experienced lawyers and more than
$1bn in recoveries. Despite the risks around opacity, we view Burford as a
high-return, high-margin and low-leverage business operating in a large,
under-penetrated market where investment outcomes are uncorrelated to
economic activity or financial markets. We reiterate our Buy
recommendation.

Finlay "The government has announced that most imports into the UK would not attract a tariff in the event of a no-deal Brexit.Under a temporary scheme 87% of imports by value would be eligible for zero-tariff access."
11:59 am
BE11:59am

And Canaccord.

LegalEagle David Allen Green of FT suggests that revocation of A50 notification is the only 'rational decision'. https://twitter.com/davidallengreen/status/1105793166651854848
BE11:59am

• Headline returns remain impressive. The ROIC on the core litigation finance investment portfolio was 85% and the IRR is c.30%.
• The ROE at the group level was 30% (34% excluding the 2018 new share issue).
• However, the results are subject to significant unrealised gains (55% of income).
• Investment Mgt. income of $15.8m was only +1% YoY and disappointingly 26% below our forecast. This accounted for under 4% of group revenue.
• Today's results show another year of impressive growth YoY. However, they do not change our view that as the business matures and deploys increasing levels of capital into alternative business lines, the return on invested capital achieved and hence the ROE will moderate.

BE11:59am

Forecasts
• Our current forecasts call for CY19 Adj. PBT of $221.7m, rising to $339.0m in CY20.
• Our Adj. EPS forecasts are $0.94 and $1.44 respectively. Alternatively, 73.8p in CY19,
rising to 112.8p in CY20.
• We currently forecast a NAV per share of 535.3p in CY19, rising to 633.9p in CY20.
Valuation & recommendation
• Our existing forecasts therefore imply Burford is trading on a CY19 PE of 24.6x, falling
to 16.1x and yields 0.6% rising to 0.7%.
• However, as evidenced by these results and the comments above re. the investment
management business, we do not think a PE or sum-of-the-parts methodology is the
best way to approach valuation.
• Instead, we prefer to focus on a P/NAV approach (target 2.3x), based on our forecast
for CY19 NAV of £1,493m, plus an estimate for $390m of unrealised Peterson gains.
• This results is our Target Price of 1543p, 15% potential downside. SELL.

red @Finlayi would look at the word temporary, this suggests getting through the first few weeks. after which they must bring them in again otherwise arranging fta is a pointless exercise.
12:00 pm

BE12:04pm

Barclays:

BE12:04pm

Prudential reported operating profits of £4.8bn, 5% (or £229m) above consensus and 1% above our estimates, and equivalent to 3% YoY growth. However, the results were helped by £330m of net one-off items (some of which were in estimates), and the underlying results were likely in-line with estimates. The company benefited from £441m of longevity releases in the UK (FY17 £204m – consensus likely around this number), £166m of insurance recovery in UK, offset by £194m negative DAC impact in the US due to lower US markets (FY17 £83m benefit, Barclays assumed £63m headwind). Asia earnings were clean, with earnings increasing 10% on actual exchange rate basis, driven by continued new business growth and shift towards higher margin health and protection business (70% of Asia revenues). Asia growth led by Hong Kong (+33%), Singapore (+22%) and China (+20%) and H2 Asia sales increased by 8% (vs 4% decline in H1). The dividend was increased by 5% to 49.35p (in line with their policy of 5% increases and step ups when justified, but behind consensus and our estimates), while Solvency 2 Capital was strong at 232% (FY17 202%) and US RBC capital improved to 458% even with headwind from US tax reform (35 points).

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

And Morgan Stanley.

BE12:05pm

Prudential has reported a 5% beat to consensus IFRS profits, driven by the UK - which was supported by longevity releases and an insurance recovery. The US - as expected, was weaker given accelerated DAC amortisation and lower spread profits - but still missed expectations. However, Jackson's hedging appears to have worked - with a robust RBC ratio of 458%. The group solvency ratio is inline at 232%, while the DPS - although a slight miss - grew by 5% YoY. In Asia,
Indonesia new business profits were weak (£122m -FY18) - and China is notably now a larger contributor (£149m). On the demerger there is a comment that most of the Rothesay annuity porfolio will be transferred by Part VII by 30 June 2019 - we believe this is faster than might have been expected.

Today's numbers make no difference. Here's Canaccord to say that.

BE12:07pm

Financial review
Results were in line with our forecasts, with the exception of the DPS which was ahead.
Key highlights as follows:
• Adj. PBT £153.5m, +82% YoY (CGe: £151.1m)
• Adj. EPS 46.5p, +27% YoY (CGe: 45.8p)
• DPS 10.0p, yield of 1.8% (CGe: 4.6p); consensus 8.2p
Canaccord Genuity view
• We note a 1% deterioration in the Vanquis bad debt charge would equate to an 8% hit
to Group PBT. At this stage of the credit cycle we see this being a very real risk.
Forecasts
• We are forecasting growth in Group Adj. PBT to £176.7m in CY19, increasing to
£197.9m in CY20.
• This gives Adj. EPS of 51.7p rising to 59.8p respectively.
• At Vanquis, we forecast a decline in divisional PBT to £177.2m in CY19 and then
£172.0m in CY20.
• We anticipate a narrowing of losses in CCD to -£13.3m in CY19, returning to a profit of
£9.0m in CY20.
• At Moneybarn, we see PBT increasing to £34.8m in CY19, rising again to £40.0m in
CY20.
Valuation & recommendation
• Our recommendation and target price (TP) on PFG prior to the NSF offer was Sell and
426p.
• Post offer, we upgraded to HOLD with a TP of 595p. NSF's offer (8.88 new NSF shares
for each PFG share) would see PFG shareholders own 87.8% of the enlarged Group.
• At the current price of 59.6p per NSF share, this implies a 529p share price for PFG
and 6% downside.
• PFG currently trades on a CY19 PE of 10.9x, falling to 9.4x and yields 6.6% rising to
7.6%.
Summary
• We do not see NSF's offer as ideal. We have a number of concerns/questions
regarding the proposal and it certainly carries risk, one of which is capital strength, as
it is for PFG as a standalone entity.
• However, we think it is unlikely that there will be a competing offer for PFG, either in
part or whole and therefore would recommend that PFG
